clinical_study.brief_title: Pilot Testing for Midline Measuring Device
clinical_study.official_title: Pilot Testing for Midline Measuring Device

brief_summary.textblock: Identifying the exact middling on the patient's head during the planning phase of surgery is crucial yet can be challenged by patient's head position and hair. Our group have invented a device that uses anatomical landmark to quickly and gracefully identify the midline on a patient's head. The device is a U-shaped instrument (pictures provided in a separate attachment to this project irb) equipped with a laser pointer at the midline. The instrument also has smooth spheres that can be positioned over the patients' ears bilaterally. The midline laser pointer will identify the midline on the patients' head. this measurement procedure is typically done after the patient is placed under anesthesia. The standard way of determining the midline on the skull is simply by surgeon's vision without any measurements. This new technique will be contrasted against the standard way. The device was invented by our group in neurosurgery (led by D Matthew Howard). We have not patented it at this time. There is no company involved in manufacturing (we were able to assemble it with the help of the hospital's machine shop)

primary_outcome.description: Does the device indicate the midline correctly based on the postop CT scan

arm_group.description: Patients undergoing ventriculoperitoneal surgery where the midline localizer was used

intervention.description: a midline localizer device with a laser pointer is used to localize where the midline is likely to be located on the patient head prior to the surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus who are scheduled to undergo a ventriculoperitoneal shunt surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are not able to consent
